title: Ron Simons, Who Brought Black Stories to Broadway, Dies at 63
description: Ron Simons, who left his job as an executive at Microsoft to pursue his dream of acting but later found his métier as a theatrical producer — one of the relatively few Black ones on Broadway — and won four Tony Awards, died on June 12. He was 63.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,100, June 23, 2024
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: A No-Fuss, Fantastic Eggplant Recipe
description: It recently dawned on me that a significant portion of my favorite, most-repeated New York Times Cooking recipes rely on eggplant. There’s Kay Chun’s eggplant dal and eggplant adobo, Alexa Weibel’s eggplant caponata pasta and this trio of stunners from Eric Kim: gochujang-glazed eggplant, bulgogi eggplant, eggplant Parm. These recipes take this very dependable vegetable and add big flavor, with the eggplant mostly providing its soft silkiness — a winning formula any time of year.

title: Secret Service Details Security Plans for the Republican National Convention
description: A Milwaukee park that is a few blocks from the arena hosting the Republican National Convention and has been at the center of a free speech lawsuit will be off limits to protesters during next month’s event, the Secret Service revealed, following intense lobbying by convention organizers.

title: Israeli Military Says Troops Tied a Wounded Palestinian to a Vehicle
description: Israeli troops tied a wounded Palestinian to the top of a military vehicle on Saturday morning during an operation in the occupied West Bank, a scene that was captured on video and quickly went viral, prompting outrage and the promise of an investigation by Israel’s military.

title: Heat-Related Illnesses Spiked in Some Regions This Past Week, C.D.C. Data Shows
description: Heat-related emergency room visits spiked this week in regions of the United States that have been hit the hardest by the heat wave, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Jeremy Tepper, SiriusXM’s Longtime Alt-Country Impresario, Dies at 60
description: Jeremy Tepper, who over a long and varied career as a journalist, singer, label owner and radio producer championed the anarchic, high-energy music that straddled the lines separating country, rock, punk and plain old Americana, died on June 14 in Queens. He was 60.

title: New Book Paints Trump as Wounded, Forgetful and Hung Up on Hollywood
description: It was May 2021, and Donald J. Trump was wounded. Four months earlier, his supporters had ransacked the Capitol. He had departed Washington, disgraced, defeated and twice impeached. His party had abandoned him, however temporarily, and he’d been kicked off his social media accounts. He holed up inside Trump Tower and stewed.

title: 3 Columbia Deans Placed on Leave Over Conduct at Antisemitism Panel
description: Columbia University placed three administrators on leave this week, a university spokesman said on Saturday. The moves came a little more than a week after images emerged showing the school officials sharing disparaging text messages during a panel discussion about antisemitism on campus.

title: After Hajj Deaths, Egypt Suspends Companies That Took Pilgrims to Mecca
description: After hundreds of pilgrims died in the scorching desert heat during the annual hajj pilgrimage to Mecca, the Egyptian government announced on Saturday that it had suspended the licenses of 16 tour companies that had facilitated travel for some pilgrims to Saudi Arabia.

title: After Conviction, Trump Presents Himself as a Martyr to the Christian Right
description: Former President Donald J. Trump addressed the evangelical Faith & Freedom Coalition in Washington on Saturday, presenting himself as a champion of religious freedom and a martyr for Americans of faith while denouncing what he described as a mass persecution of Christians.

title: Thousands of Michigan Residents Weather Days Without Power During Heat Wave
description: As storms battered southeast Michigan this week, Lindsey Brenz heard trees crashing and saw bright flashes of lightning through her windows. Then, she heard a pop and the monotone drone of what she suspected was a power surge.

title: Silvano Marchetto, Owner of Glitzy Greenwich Village Trattoria, Dies at 77
description: Silvano Marchetto, an Italian-born restaurateur whose Greenwich Village trattoria, Da Silvano, became a star-studded canteen and a Page Six fixture over four decades, died on June 4 in Florence, Italy. He was 77.

title: Picture Day
description: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

title: A Parade of Mermaids Marches On in Brooklyn’s Coney Island
description: Dolly McDermott and her mother, Patricia McDermott, were making their way along Surf Avenue on Coney Island shortly after noon on Saturday. They were trying to get to the registration table for Brooklyn’s annual Mermaid Parade, but it was slow going — spectators kept asking them to pose for pictures.

title: Trump Hawks American Flag Pins with His Name in Gold Splashed Across Them
description: Donald J. Trump’s campaign is billing it as a must-have fashion accessory for his supporters: an American flag lapel pin with the former president’s name scrawled in gold block letters across it — in all caps.

title: A Tourist From New Mexico Is Killed by an Elephant in Zambia
description: A tourist from New Mexico was killed in Zambia when an elephant charged her, according to the police commissioner who investigated the incident. She is the second tourist to be fatally attacked by an elephant in the southern African country this year.

title: A Tenacious and Wild Pekingese Is the Ugliest Dog, After Five Tries
description: Maybe it’s the way his lolling pink tongue juts out, or how his glittering wide eyes bejewel a tiny head under a mop of long, frizzy, brown-and-white fur, but there’s just something about Wild Thang — and a panel of judges agreed.

title: Donald Trump Said He Proposed a ‘Migrant League of Fighters’
description: Former President Donald J. Trump said in an address to an evangelical group that he had suggested starting a sports league for migrants to fight one another.

title: Grocery Store Shooting That Killed 4 Leaves an Arkansas Town in Disbelief
description: Thomas and Sharon Brazil were sitting in their car late Friday morning in front of the only grocery store in Fordyce, Ark., discussing what they wanted to buy to put on the grill that night. Then they noticed a man with a gun approaching them.

title: Trump Suggests Biden May Use Supplements to Get ‘Jacked Up’ for Debate
description: In his last scheduled rally before he takes the stage for a presidential debate, former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday mocked President Biden over his preparations, suggesting his opponent might be using medical supplements.

title: Quote of the Day: Defying and Disrupting, Putin Succeeds in Asia
description: “He’s quite happy for Russia to be the smelliest, farting uncle at the barbecue.”

title: Why Southeast Asia Is Crying Over This Movie
description: Daniel Nico Laudit says he does not cry easily. He decided to test his mettle this month in a movie theater in Manila and documented the experience for his 4.5 million followers on TikTok.

title: The Man Softening the Ground for an Extremist Germany
description: From the small stage of a pub in a wooded town of eastern Germany, the right-wing ideologue Björn Höcke regaled a crowd of followers late last year with the tale of his imminent trial. He faced charges for saying “Everything for Germany” at a political rally — breaking German laws against uttering Nazi slogans.

title: What the Arrival of A.I. Phones and Computers Means for Our Data
description: Apple, Microsoft and Google are heralding a new era of what they describe as artificially intelligent smartphones and computers. The devices, they say, will automate tasks like editing photos and wishing a friend a happy birthday.

title: Boys Are Struggling. Male Kindergarten Teachers Are Here to Help.
description: Only around 3 percent of kindergarten teachers are men. We interviewed a dozen of them about the joys of the job and the challenges boys face today.

title: The Nation Resurgent, and Borders, Too
description: At the heart of the rapid rise of the nationalist right, with its view of immigrants as a direct threat to the essence of France, there appears to lie a growing feeling among many French people that they are no longer at home in their own country.

title: Corrections: June 23, 2024
description: An article on Page 1 this weekend about the role that marijuana may have played in the accidental death of a teenager misstates the location of an outing taken by Nico Nuño-Kelley and his mother. It was in Bedford, N.Y., not Connecticut.

title: Lauren Boebert Is Feeling the Heat in Colorado
description: “Man, I hit a wall,” Lauren Boebert said, sounding ready to pack it in.

title: The E.U. Is Revealing Its True Identity. Europeans Don’t Like It.
description: In European Parliament elections this month, voters in most of the European Union’s 27 countries rallied to parties that hold the union in contempt. Analysts have leaped to the conclusion that the European Union must have done something wrong.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: ‘I Walked Over to a Food Cart That Is Always at the Intersection’
description: Dear Diary:

title: Hidden Stashes: Keeping Money Secrets From a Loved One
description: Ric Shahin wanted to surprise his wife with a special trip for their 10th wedding anniversary, so he set up a secret bank account and began depositing $50 from his paycheck every two weeks. But he soon realized that although he had two and a half years to save for the trip, he wouldn’t have enough, so he increased the deposit to $150.

title: Disputes About Race and Party Strategy Shape N.Y. Democratic Primaries
description: In Brooklyn, a State Assembly race has attracted the involvement of marquee figures like Hakeem Jeffries, the House Democratic leader, and Letitia James, the New York State attorney general.

title: For Biden and Trump, a Debate Rematch With Even Greater Risks and Rewards
description: The debate between President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump this week will be the highest-stakes moment of their rematch, plunging two presidents into an extraordinarily early confrontation before a divided and angry nation.

title: Motorbikes, Nightclubs, Tricked-Out Cars: Is Rhode Island’s Capital Too Loud?
description: On the worst nights, when the thudding bass from a nearby nightclub rattled his windows and drowned out the sound on his TV, the noise in John Heaney’s home in Providence felt more like an intruder than a nuisance.

title: Blaming Hamas for Gazans’ Suffering, Many Israelis Feel Little Sympathy
description: The southern Israeli city of Netivot, a working-class hub for mystical rabbis about 10 miles from the Gaza border, escaped the worst of the Hamas-led attack of Oct. 7, a fluke many residents ascribe to miraculous intervention by the Jewish sages buried here.

title: Child Care, Cafes, Herman Miller Desks: It’s Not Your Average Gym
description: High-end gyms are no longer just places to sweat it out.

title: Why You’re Paying Your Veterinarian So Much
description: Heather Massey brought Ladybird to the veterinarian when the 9-year-old mutt began having seizures. A scan from an M.R.I. machine revealed bad news: brain cancer.

title: Michael Flynn Has Turned His Trump-World Celebrity Into a Family Business
description: In 2021, retired Gen. Michael T. Flynn, Donald J. Trump’s first national security adviser, became chairman of a 75-year-old nonprofit organization — the kind of small charity where chairmen typically work for free.

title: 4 Fun, Flirty New Romance Novels
description: It’s a great setup for a joke: A superhero walks into a gay bar and gets rescued from avid fans by a drag queen. It’s also where we begin Philip Ellis’s contemporary romance WE COULD BE HEROES (Putnam, 370 pp., paperback, $20). Patrick Lake, who plays the comic book hero Captain Kismet in the Hollywood franchise, is a closeted A-lister with a restrictive morality clause in his contract. The drag queen is Grace Anatomy, a.k.a. Will, who works nights at a bar called the Village Inn in Birmingham, England — where Patrick’s filming the latest Captain Kismet movie — and days at a used-book shop.

title: An Odd Rock in a Box Gets Linked to a Shooting Star That Fell 54 Years Ago
description: Tens of thousands of meteorites have been found on Earth, but a vast majority remain shrouded in mystery. These rocks come from space, of course, but pinning down their exact origins, in the solar system or even beyond, is difficult without knowing their flight paths.

title: In Search of My Father’s Frontier: His Years in Mao’s Army
description: I didn’t have much time. I was in the remote town of Altay in China’s far northwest region of Xinjiang, on the mountainous border with Russia, Mongolia and Kazakhstan, thousands of miles from my base in Beijing as a bureau chief for The New York Times.

title: Clippers Cut a Wide Swath Making Political Campaign Videos Go Viral
description: When Andrew Lawrence begins his night shift, he powers on his monitor to sift through Fox News’ evening programming.

title: The Late-in-Life Lesbian Experience Blossoms Online
description: When Suzette Mullen finally acknowledged her complicated feelings for the woman she considered her best friend, she felt the weight of a significant question: Am I gay?

title: Have You Heard the One About the School for Stand-Up Comedy?
description: Everyone’s a critic — and now, it seems, a comedian too. Actual one-liners are what flourish on the platform now known with titanium self-seriousness as X. “Content creators,” a terrible umbrella term that covers some very funny and talented people, are arguably your new late-night hosts, yukking it up over there on TikTok.

title: Russell Crowe’s in 2 Exorcism Films? Yes, and Here’s Why the Roles Work
description: Russell Crowe is going through a religious phase.

title: I Saw My Anxiety Reflected in ‘Inside Out 2.’ It Floored Me.
description: At the climax of Pixar’s “Inside Out 2,” Riley, a freshly pubescent teen with a gaggle of new personified emotions, becomes so overwhelmed with anxiety that she has a panic attack.

title: Big Pink Bird Makes Splash in the Hamptons
description: For the last few summers in East Hampton, N.Y., many people have gotten up early in hopes of glimpsing Jay-Z on one of his early morning walks amid the shingled mansions of moguls such as David Zaslav, David Geffen and Ron Perelman.

title: Fact-Checking Biden’s and Trump’s Claims About the Economy
description: Consumer sentiment about the state of the economy could be pivotal in shaping the 2024 presidential election.

title: 1 Dead After Floods Prompt Rescues in Iowa and South Dakota
description: Parts of the Upper Midwest remained under flood warnings on Sunday after days of heavy rain caused major flooding, leaving at least one person dead in South Dakota and forcing evacuations and water rescues across the region.

title: The Connections Companion No. 379, June 24, 2024
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,101, June 24, 2024
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: I Know What America’s Leading C.E.O.s Really Think of Donald Trump
description: Recent headlines suggest that our nation’s business leaders are embracing the presidential candidate Donald Trump. His campaign would have you believe that our nation’s top chief executives are returning to support Mr. Trump for president, touting declarations of support from some prominent financiers like Steve Schwarzman and David Sacks.

title: Celine Dion Will Go On
description: Nearly two years ago, I huddled with some co-workers over a phone watching a video Celine Dion had shared on Instagram. She announced she was canceling her European tour because she had been diagnosed with stiff person syndrome, a rare neurological disorder that had made it difficult for her to move and sing.

title: Puerto Rico Will Not Go Quietly Into the Dark
description: This month a massive outage left over 350,000 customers in San Juan, P.R., without power, including my 96-year-old grandmother and 75-year-old mom. Amid a record-breaking heat wave, my mom struggled to keep my grandmother cool with a battery-operated fan. The frustration and fear in my mother’s voice as we spoke on the phone was palpable, and when the call ended, I found myself blinking back tears of rage.

title: Clarence Thomas and John Roberts Are at a Fork in the Road
description: Two years ago, when the Supreme Court decided New York State Rifle and Pistol Association Inc. v. Bruen, it created a jurisprudential mess that scrambled American gun laws. On Friday not only did the cleanup begin, but the Supreme Court also cleared the way for one of the most promising legal innovations for preventing gun violence: red flag laws.

title: The Costs of Caring for Pets
description: Pets these days are just like us. They get birthday cakes, day care and rubber boots to wear in the snow. Their health care is becoming more human, too — for better and for worse.

title: In Germany, a Tournament Runs Smoothly, but the Trains Do Not
description: Niclas Füllkrug arrived early at the Adidas campus just outside Herzogenaurach, a picture-postcard town in Bavaria that was to host the German national team before this summer’s European soccer championships. The staff had been told that players would start arriving on a Monday morning, a few days before their opening game. But Füllkrug, one of the team’s forwards, turned up on Sunday night.

title: After Escaping China by Sea, a Dissident Faces His Next Act
description: The dissident’s lone regret after his 200-mile escape across the Yellow Sea was not taking night vision goggles.

title: A Man Missing for 10 Days in a California Forest Is Found Alive
description: On the morning of June 11, Lukas McClish stopped by the home of a friend who told him about a granite outcropping in the nearby woods that piqued his interest, so Mr. McClish set out on his own, shirtless, to explore the scenery.

title: A Recipe for Cooks Who Love to Poke at the Grill
description: Good morning. I’ve been cooking outside as much as I can these last few weeks, turning meats and vegetables over fire. Sometimes the fuel is wood, other times charcoal, many times propane. Grilled food is the song of my summer.

title: How to Deal With the National Trauma of Jan. 6
description: To the Editor:

title: Ukraine Urges Allies to Allow Their Weapons to Target Russian Air Power
description: As bombs dropped by Russian warplanes tore through residential districts in the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv this weekend, killing at least four people and injuring dozens more, President Volodymyr Zelensky on Sunday called on allies to further ease restrictions on the use of Western weapons so that his forces could use them against Russian air bases.

title: A Final, Graceful Bow From Dries Van Noten
description: “I tried to make things people would cherish,” Dries Van Noten said on Saturday evening, during a cocktail party and dinner preceding his final runway show. Mr. Van Noten held his first show in Paris back in 1991; now, at 66, he is stepping away from his namesake brand. His retirement was a shock to many in a business in which careers tend to be abnormally truncated or else to exceed their expiration date.

title: A Patriotic Tribute, a Time-Honored Tradition
description: This July, The New York Times will honor the Declaration of Independence as it has for 102 years: with a full-page tribute to the founding document.

title: Thunderstorms Lash New England After Rare Risk of Tornadoes
description: Parts of New England and the Northeast faced the rare threat of possible tornadoes on Sunday as severe thunderstorms marched across the region, forecasters said.

title: Gunmen Attack Synagogues and Churches in Russian Republic
description: Gunmen attacked synagogues and churches in two cities in southern Russia on Sunday, killing multiple police officers and a priest, in an apparently coordinated assault that underscored Russia’s vulnerability to extremist violence.

title: Woman Tried to Drown 3-Year-Old Girl After Making Racist Comments, Police Say
description: A woman in Texas was charged with attempted capital murder after she tried to drown a 3-year-old girl in an apartment complex pool after making racist comments, officials said.

title: Monday Briefing: Among Some Israelis, Muted Sympathy for Gaza
description: Some Israelis are struggling to show concern for the people suffering in Gaza, according to interviews conducted in right-wing and liberal strongholds in southern Israel, and with residents from across the country.

title: As New Jersey Bakes, Some Towns Ask Residents to Reduce Water Use
description: The intense and unusually early heat wave that has blanketed much of the Northeast for the past week continued on Sunday to scorch New Jersey, where excessive heat warnings or heat advisories were in effect in most of the state, according to the National Weather Service.

title: Pilgrim Deaths in Mecca Put Spotlight on Underbelly of Hajj Industry
description: More than 1,300 people died making the Islamic pilgrimage of hajj in Saudi Arabia this month, the vast majority of whom the Saudi government said did not have permits. Many walked for miles in scorching heat after paying thousands of dollars to illicit or fraudulent tour operators.

title: Broody Subculture
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: Why Bragg Dropped Charges Against Most Columbia Student Protesters
description: Alvin Bragg, the Manhattan district attorney, last week dropped most of the 46 cases against pro-Palestinian demonstrators charged in the April 30 siege of Hamilton Hall at Columbia University because prosecutors had little proof that the cases would stand up at trial.

title: No Apparent Motive in Arkansas Shooting, but the Reaction Is ‘So Personal’
description: The gunman who opened fire on Friday at a grocery store in Fordyce, Ark., killing four people and hurting 10 others, did not appear to target anyone, officials say, or have any known links to the victims. But the officers in the town of 3,400 who rushed there and eventually subdued the assailant could not have felt more connected.

title: Gabbi Tuft, First Openly Trans Former W.W.E. Star, Returns to Wrestling
description: Gabbi Tuft, a former World Wrestling Entertainment star and the first current or former member of the organization to come out as transgender, will return to the ring this month, she said on social media on Sunday.

title: No Corrections: June 24, 2024
description: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

title: F.B.I. Offers Reward for Information About New Mexico Wildfires
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is offering an award for information about two wildfires in southern New Mexico that left two people dead, prompted the evacuation of thousands and scorched more than 24,000 acres.

title: ‘House of the Dragon’ Season 2, Episode 2 Recap: Sleep With One Eye Open
description: Not even Rhaenyra Targaryen can believe what she’s seeing.

title: Man Charged With Murder After a Triple Stabbing in Manhattan
description: A man was charged with murder on Monday after three people were stabbed, one fatally, in the East Village on Sunday, police officials said.

title: Japan and South Korea Are Fighting Over an App at a Tense Time
description: A joint venture set up in 2019 by two top Japanese and South Korean companies was hailed as a beacon of cooperation amid strained diplomatic relations.

title: Monday Briefing
description: The intensive phase of Israel’s war against Hamas “is about to end,” Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said yesterday, adding that he did not mean that the conflict was over.

title: What’s on TV This Week: The Presidential Debate and CMA Fest
description: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, June 24-30. Details and times are subject to change.

description: The word expatriate has appeared in 39 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 3 in “In Australia and New Zealand, Barefoot Is a Way of Life” by Natasha Frost:
