description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: Fake Signatures and ‘Good-Faith Letters’ Fuel a Lucrative Campaign Haul
description: When an unheralded candidate for the State Assembly submitted a six-figure request for matching funds under New York’s new public campaign finance system, it came with glaring red flags.

title: It’s the Golden Age of Weird Vehicles
description: This is Street Wars, a weekly series on the battle for space on New York’s streets and sidewalks.

title: In This Debate, CNN Is the Decider
description: The prime-time matchup on Thursday between President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump represents an evening full of promise and peril.

title: Formula 1 Tickets and a Fixation on Gold: Menendez Trial Takeaways
description: After a month and a half of testimony from government witnesses, lawyers for Senator Robert Menendez this week are expected to begin rebutting the web of corruption charges facing New Jersey’s senior senator, once one of the most powerful Democrats in Washington.

title: What to Know About Jamaal Bowman’s Bitter Democratic Primary Race
description: When Representative Jamaal Bowman of New York won a Democratic primary in 2020 as an untested middle-school principal, his upset was heralded as evidence of the left’s ascent.

title: Fire at Lithium Battery Plant in South Korea Kills 22
description: A fire at a lithium battery factory near Seoul​ on Monday killed 22 workers, most of them migrant laborers from China, in one of the deadliest blazes in South Korea in years, officials said.

title: For One Night Only, Paris Is Vogue’s (Disney)World
description: On Sunday evening, in honor of International Olympic Day and just before the couture shows began, Anna Wintour, the editor of American Vogue and global chief content director of Condé Nast, flexed her muscles.

title: Apple Is First Company Charged Under New E.U. Competition Law
description: Apple is imposing unfair restrictions on developers of applications for its App Store in violation of a new European Union law meant to encourage competition in the tech industry, regulators in Brussels said on Monday.

title: Philippines Drops Charges Against Leila de Lima, Prominent Duterte Critic
description: Leila de Lima, a former senator in the Philippines who was detained for six years after she criticized President Rodrigo Duterte’s war on drugs, was cleared on Monday of the last of the charges that the authorities had held her on.

title: Tomi Adeyemi’s Books Are Fantasy. What They Taught Her Is Painfully Real.
description: Something was in the air — though Tomi Adeyemi couldn’t quite say what. It wasn’t the sweltering heat of a New York City summer, nor the perfume of the sweat that had gathered atop our skin.

title: An Adoptee’s Search for Her Birth Mother, Pandemic Be Damned
description: Four years ago, the novelist Tracy O’Neill was languishing in her Brooklyn apartment, fresh out of a long-term relationship, when she got to thinking about her birth mother in South Korea, whom she’d never known. City life was a morass of P.C.R. tests and Zoom classes — O’Neill is an assistant professor at Vassar College — and she became fixated on the idea of a mother “who, if not dead, could be dying alone.”

title: Have Refrigerators Spoiled Everything?
description: Consider the improbable fact of the supermarket banana. In “Frostbite,” an exploration of the vast system known as the cold chain, the journalist Nicola Twilley follows the banana through a “seamless network of thermal control.” This series of refrigerated trucks, rail cars, shipping containers and warehouses ends in the ripening room, with its temperature gauges and gas immersion baths, all to meet our demand for ripe tropical fruit in all seasons. “Produce is a labor of love,” a warehouse owner tells her. “I tell people that working here is like a face tattoo — you’ve got to be really sure you want it.”

title: Affordable Island-Hopping in Croatia? What Could Go Wrong?
description: As Croatians tell the story, the Greek hero Odysseus was shipwrecked and held captive on the Croatian island of Mljet. Visiting in May, I and six other sailors embraced the myth when the motor on our 54-foot yacht failed.

title: Discord at the Symphony: Losing a Star, San Francisco Weighs Its Future
description: For a night at the symphony, there was a lot of tension in the air.

title: Many African Nations Want France Out. This Country Wants It In.
description: After decades of wielding political, military and economic power across Africa, France is scaling back its presence on the continent as it faces significant resentment in many African countries. Yet one nation has emerged as an exception: Rwanda.

title: In San Francisco, Doctors Feud Over ‘Do No Harm’ When It Comes to War Protests
description: It looked like any other pro-Palestinian encampment at a college campus in the United States. The tents, the flags, the banners calling for a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war.

title: These Victorian Lampshades Are a TikTok Hit
description: When Ivy Karlsgodt set out to make her first vintage-inspired lampshade, she took her time: She sketched out a design, gathered her materials and spent hours carefully cutting and stitching pieces of chiffon, silk and velvet onto a metal frame in the shape of a drooping tulip. The end result had gold and red fabrics overlaid with sheer pleating and long black fringe.

title: How Support for Britain’s Conservative Party Is Collapsing
description: The party that has dominated British politics through crisis after crisis could secure its lowest share of seats in Parliament in a century.

title: Their Job Is to Help You Grieve Your Pet
description: Amy Conroy sat alone in a veterinary exam room, hands clutching a water bottle, eyes blinking back tears. Her 16-year-old cat, Leisel, had been having trouble breathing. Now, she was waiting for an update.

title: Is Fish Oil Helpful or Harmful for the Heart?
description: In 1970, two Danish researchers traveled to Greenland to investigate a nutritional paradox: The Inuit people living in the region consumed foods very high in fat, yet reportedly had very low rates of heart attacks.

title: There’s Food for Everyone on Earth. So Why Is Hunger Getting Worse?
description: In 2004, Jean-Martin Bauer was doing humanitarian work in southern Mauritania when he met a woman named Binta living with her children in a patched-up tent by a dry riverbed. A member of the oppressed Haratin caste, Binta often struggled to feed her kids, and had developed a trick to cover for that: “At night,” she told Bauer, “I gather the pots and pans, and build a fire. I pour out water into the large pot. I act just as though I am making dinner. And if my kids become suspicious and start asking me when dinner is ready, I snap at them and tell them: ‘Quiet! Can’t you see I’m cooking?’” When they’d finally fall asleep, she’d stop the charade.

title: The Mysterious, Deep-Dwelling Microbes That Sculpt Our Planet
description: In the middle of North America, there is a portal to the deep recesses of Earth’s rocky interior. The portal’s mouth — a furrowed pit about half a mile wide — spirals 1,250 feet into the ground, expos­ing a marbled mosaic of young and ancient rock: gray bands of basalt, milky veins of quartz and shimmering con­stellations of gold. Beneath the pit, some 370 miles of tunnels twist through solid rock, extending more than 1.5 miles below the surface. For 126 years, this site in Lead, S.D., housed the Homestake Mine, the deepest and most productive gold mine on the continent.

title: Recent High School Grads: Tell Us Why You Decided to Go to College or Not
description: Polls, enrollment statistics, social media posts and education economists agree: We are seeing a growing skepticism of college among many American teenagers and their parents.

title: $2.4 Million Homes in California
description: This house, among the first to be built on its street, is a few blocks from Lake Avenue, one of the area’s main thoroughfares. It is less than a 10-minute walk from a coffee shop, a hardware store and a Thai restaurant, and within a 15-minute walk of a public library and an Aldi supermarket. Charles S. Farnsworth Park, which has an amphitheater and a playground, is about a five-minute drive.

title: A Tense Time for Parks, Libraries and the Arts
description: Good morning. It’s Monday. The clock is ticking on the city’s budget negotiations. We’ll examine what’s at stake. We’ll also look at how Representative Jamaal Bowman turned to national star power going into the Democratic primary on Tuesday.

title: I’m a Doctor and a Voter. Here’s How I’m Thinking About the Health of Trump and Biden.
description: Among the most fraught questions about this election is the health of the aging candidates themselves.

title: America Got Gay Marriage, but It Came at a Cost
description: It’s a strange time for gay rights in America. As the country nears the 10th anniversary of the legalization of gay marriage nationwide, support for it has risen to 70 percent of the American public. But at the same time, L.G.B.T.Q. people are being targeted in ways not seen since the days of Save Our Children, Anita Bryant’s infamous 1977 campaign against gay rights that depicted gay men as human garbage and pedophiles.

title: Chess Players Wonder if Being a Grandmaster Still Has Meaning
description: When the International Chess Federation created the inaugural list of grandmasters, the game’s highest title, in 1950, there were 27. Today, there are more than 1,850.

title: Responsibility Over Freedom: How Netflix’s Culture Has Changed
description: Netflix has long been a company known for its secrets: no Nielsen ratings, little feedback on why shows are canceled, no box office numbers for the rare movies that are actually released in theaters.

title: Abortion Debate Shifts as Election Nears: ‘Now It’s About Pregnancy’
description: In the decades that Roe v. Wade was the law of the land, abortion rights groups tried to shore up support for it by declaring “Abortion Is Health Care.”

title: Our Pandemic Puppy Brought Pure Joy. Losing Him, Pure Heartbreak.
description: The first good thing about Rascal was his wiggling, leaping “You’re awake!” greeting at the start of every day. My husband loves me, and my children love me, but not one human being has ever been as glad to see me as that buoyant little dog was every single morning of his life in our house.

title: A.I. Is Getting Better Fast. Can You Tell What’s Real Now?
description: Test your skills in this quiz.

title: Is Lauren Boebert Too ‘Radically Lauren Boebert’ for Colorado?
description: Representative Lauren Boebert is coming up on a primary that will determine her political future. Times Opinion writer Michelle Cottle traveled to Colorado to follow her campaign as she vies for a new district. Tuesday’s primary, Cottle argues, will “tell us something about the limits of extreme Trumpism by candidates not named Trump, and also how much room these candidates have to maneuver within the strictures of the MAGAverse.”

title: On Dobbs Anniversary, Democrats Look to Make the Court a Campaign Issue
description: A Democratic-leaning group announced on Monday the beginning of a seven-figure campaign to focus voter attention on the importance of the Supreme Court in the presidential election, with a heavy emphasis on the high court’s role in issues like abortion, gun safety and voting rights.

title: ‘House of the Dragon’: Elliott and Luke Tittensor on That Brutal Duel
description: This interview contains spoilers for Season 2, Episode 2 of “House of the Dragon.”

title: How Short Is Too Short for a Skirt?
description: Even before Ally McBeal spawned a cottage industry of should-you-or-shouldn’t-you chatter by wearing exceedingly short skirts to her law firm in the 1990s sitcom, and before Mary Quant rocked the fashion world with the miniskirt in the 1960s, Gussie Moran caused a ruckus in the tennis world in 1949 by chopping the knee-length playing skirt to upper thigh, the better to move around the court. Tennis fans quailed, Wimbledon authorities freaked, and Ms. Moran, nicknamed “Gorgeous Gussie,” was charged with bringing “vulgarity and sin into tennis.”

title: In Abortion Cases, Legions of ‘Friends’ Seek to Persuade Supreme Court
description: When the Supreme Court decided Roe v. Wade in 1973, establishing a constitutional right to abortion, it noted that it had received 14 friend-of-the-court briefs and listed them in a snug footnote at the beginning of the decision.

title: The Little Secret I’ve Learned From 30 Years of Watching Debates With Voters
description: If you’re a typical American voter in any party, allow me to let you in on a little secret: What matters most to you in a presidential debate probably isn’t the same thing that gets the most attention from the candidates, the campaigns and their allies in the immediate aftermath of those big televised showdowns.

title: Drawn-Out Heat Wave Expected to Finally Let Up in Many Parts of the U.S.
description: The unusually early heat wave that shattered temperature records across the Northeast, Mid-Atlantic States and Midwest last week is expected to subside by Monday, bringing relief to tens of millions of Americans.

title: Democrats Lean on Abortion Rights Message for Anniversary of End of Roe
description: Two years after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, unleashing a cascade of state-level abortion bans and prompting an angry political backlash, Democrats are marking the anniversary by highlighting the role former President Donald J. Trump played in ending the constitutional right to an abortion.

title: Wading Through Neck-High Waters in Iowa, a Husband Implored His Wife to Keep Going
description: Wanda and Randy Bliek awoke on Saturday to the sound of water lapping against the walls of their home in Rock Valley, Iowa.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,102, June 25, 2024
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: The Connections Companion No. 380, June 25, 2024
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Biden Attacks Trump on Abortion, and an Illicit Hajj Industry
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: The Army of Poets and Students Fighting a Forgotten War
description: Warning: this episode contains descriptions of injuries.

title: The Promise of Weight-Loss Drugs
description: In the past two years, Ozempic has become a synonym for weight loss. When celebrities slimmed down, tabloids wondered whether they were taking the drug. Activists argued that the drug entrenched old norms about body image — people still seemed to want to be thin. Ozempic was weight loss; weight loss was Ozempic. It’s like Kleenex or Scotch tape: totemic.

title: The Deadly Flooding Tearing Through Southern China, in Photos
description: At least 47 people have died in southern China’s Guangdong Province after torrential rains set off flooding and landslides, according to the Chinese authorities.

title: Dissident Rapper’s Death Sentence Overturned in Iran, His Lawyer Says
description: Iran’s supreme court has overturned the death sentence of a dissident rapper who backed nationwide protests, according to his lawyer, reversing an April decision that had brought widespread criticism and outrage from human rights organizations and others.

title: Deadly Attack Revives Fears of the Return of Mass Terror in Russia
description: A deadly attack on a police station and places of worship in southern Russia on Sunday raised the specter of a new wave of violence in the country’s restive Northern Caucasus region and underlined the mounting security challenges facing the Kremlin amid the demands of the war in Ukraine.

title: Apple’s European Headache
description: Apple’s feud with global regulators escalated after the European Union on Monday charged the iPhone maker with stifling competition on its App Store, a breach that carries potentially big penalties and could upend a hugely profitable area of the tech giant’s business.

title: Princess Anne Hospitalized With Minor Injuries
description: Princess Anne, the younger sister of King Charles III, was hospitalized on Sunday evening after suffering a concussion and other minor injuries in an unspecified accident, Buckingham Palace said on Monday.

title: Unlikely Wild Animals Are Being Smuggled Into U.S. Ports: Corals
description: You might imagine that when federal wildlife inspectors search for illegally trafficked animal goods, they’d be on the lookout for elephant ivory or tiger skins. But other creatures are frequently being seized at American ports of entry, creatures you perhaps would not realize are animals: corals.

title: How Many Abortion Seekers Are Traveling to California
description: After the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade and some states, mainly in the South, banned abortions altogether, many Americans began crossing state lines to get one.

title: The Chef Is Human. The Reviewer Isn’t.
description: The White Clam Pizza at Frank Pepe Pizzeria Napoletana in New Haven, Conn., is a revelation. The crust, kissed by the intense heat of the coal-fired oven, achieves a perfect balance of crispness and chew. Topped with freshly shucked clams, garlic, oregano and a dusting of grated cheese, it is a testament to the magic that simple, high-quality ingredients can conjure.

title: Game Reviews: Escape the Heat by Ascending an Ocean Throne
description: During the early summer days of oppressive heat, Crab God, Riven and Rabbids: Legends of the Multiverse offer tantalizing virtual experiences in refreshing ocean biomes, a lush science fiction land and cool medieval villages.

title: Supreme Court Will Hear Challenge to Tennessee Law Banning Transition Care for Minors
description: The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to consider a Tennessee law that bans certain medical treatments for transgender minors, the first time the justices will decide on the constitutionality of such statewide bans.

title: Do You Know Where These Classic Novels Are Set?
description: Summer is here! Try this short quiz about books that happen to be set in popular vacation destinations.

title: A Global Push Fixed the Ozone Hole. Satellites Could Threaten It.
description: Low-Earth orbit, a layer of superhighway that wraps around Earth’s thermosphere some 200 to 600 miles above our heads, is newly congested.

title: Pasta Nada for Meh Mondays
description: Hello! Mia here, filling in for Melissa Clark today. How are you? I’m … tired. Maybe it’s the heat, maybe it’s just Monday, but I’m slow and sluggish, the human equivalent of that womp-womp trombone noise. I need a dinner that knows how bleh I am but also knows I’m hungry and want something substantial and nourishing. I need pasta nada.

title: How a 1933 Book About Jews in Magic Was Rescued From Oblivion
description: Richard Hatch was searching the card catalog of the Sterling Memorial Library at Yale, hunting for intriguing titles under the subject heading “Magic.” It was 1979, and Hatch was a young graduate student in physics, but he’d long nurtured an amateur’s passion for the conjuring arts and, on this day at least, he preferred to read about sleight of hand than quantum mechanics.

title: Iran’s Onerous Hijab Law for Women Is Now a Campaign Issue
description: Iranian officials insisted for decades that the law requiring women to cover their hair and dress modestly was sacrosanct and not even worth discussion. They dismissed the struggle by women who challenged the law as a symptom of Western meddling.

title: More Than 1,000 Hajj Pilgrims Died. Here’s What to Know.
description: At least 1,300 people died during the annual hajj pilgrimage in Mecca this year. It was unclear whether the death toll was higher than usual, as each year pilgrims die from heat stress, illness and chronic disease.

title: ‘It’s All Happening Again.’ The Supply Chain Is Under Strain.
description: Stephanie Loomis had hoped that the chaos besieging the global supply chain was subsiding. The floating traffic jams off ports. The multiplying costs of moving freight. The resulting shortages of goods. All of this had seemed like an unpleasant memory confined to the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Fearing Losses, Banks Are Quietly Dumping Real Estate Loans
description: Some Wall Street banks, worried that landlords of vacant and struggling office buildings won’t be able to pay off their mortgages, have begun offloading their portfolios of commercial real estate loans hoping to cut their losses.

title: Extreme Wildfires Have Doubled in 2 Decades, Study Finds
description: The hottest year on record, 2023, was also the most extreme for wildfires, according to new research.

title: Is Delaying Menopause the Key to Longevity?
description: In March, the first lady, Jill Biden, announced a new White House women’s health initiative that highlighted a seemingly obscure research question: What if you could delay menopause and all the health risks associated with it?

title: C.E.O.s Are Frustrated. That Doesn’t Mean They Embrace Trump.
description: When the White House chief of staff, Jeffrey Zients, met with dozens of top executives in Washington this month, he encountered a familiar list of corporate complaints about President Biden.

title: Should Social Media Come With Warning Labels?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hollywood Sharpens Aim at Online Pirates
description: In recent years, Hollywood has become much better at hunting pirates. Just last week, five men were convicted of operating Jetflicks, an illegal streaming site that federal prosecutors said offered a stolen lineup of TV shows and movies that was larger than the combined catalogs of Netflix, Hulu and Amazon’s Prime Video.

title: Charli XCX’s ‘Brat’ Breakthrough
description: The iconoclastic pop star Charli XCX has long flirted with mainstream success — helping write Icona Pop’s omnipresent 2012 hit “I Love It,” appearing on the hook of Iggy Azalea’s smash “Fancy” and in 2014 scoring a Top 10 hit of her own with “Boom Clap” — but largely exists as a self-proclaimed “cult classic,” a denizen of the club underground known for a string of innovative but niche records. Charli’s brash, strobe-lit sixth album, “Brat,” is in some ways her most daring release yet, but — improbably — it’s also her most commercially successful, debuting at No. 3 in the United States and earning her highest opening-week sales in her native United Kingdom.

title: Virginia Woolf, but Make It a Polyphonic, Sensory Ballet
description: In a rehearsal room at American Ballet Theater’s studios earlier this month, Alessandra Ferri and Roman Zhurbin paused during a pas de deux, waiting to take their next steps. “Where’s Big Ben?” Ferri asked. “We need to hear the bells.”

title: 2 Candidates. No Audience. 29 New York Times Fact-Checkers.
description: How do you cover a historic presidential debate that includes a candidate convicted of 34 felonies in what he has called, without evidence, a “rigged trial,” and that will air on TV absent an audience? With a few dozen reporters and fact-checkers.

title: Politicians Can Bend the Truth. Here’s How We Bend It Back.
description: True or false is fine for pop quizzes and trivia games, but in politics, things are rarely that clear-cut.

title: Biden and Democratic Leaders Condemn Protest Outside L.A. Synagogue as Antisemitic
description: A protest outside of a synagogue in Los Angeles’s most densely populated Jewish enclave on Sunday drew unusually swift and forceful condemnation from top Democratic leaders including President Biden, reigniting debates about the boundaries of acceptable protest as tensions over the war in Gaza continue to flare across the country.

title: Rapper Known as Julio Foolio Is Fatally Shot in Florida
description: The rapper known as Julio Foolio was killed in a shooting in a hotel parking lot in Tampa, Fla., on Sunday, during a weekend of birthday celebrations, which included events that he had announced on his social media account. Three other people were wounded in the shooting, according to the police.

title: In Greece, Another Tourist Found Dead Amid Scorching Heat Wave
description: Greek authorities said on Monday that the body of a missing German man was recovered near a gorge on the island of Crete, the latest in a series of fatal incidents involving tourists undertaking demanding hikes in the scorching heat.

title: 4 Scenarios for Next Phase in Gaza War, With ‘Intense’ Fighting Set to End
description: Israel’s prime minister says the war in the Gaza Strip will soon enter a new phase.

title: Mabe Fratti, a Spark in Mexico City’s Experimental Music Scene
description: Ten years ago, the cellist and experimental composer Mabe Fratti came across a strange painting by Paul Klee. “Angelus Novus” depicts an angel, wings splayed, eyes wide open, who looks as though he is about to flutter away from whatever he is looking at. “It’s a metaphor for history,” she said, video calling from her friend’s living room couch in Berlin. “The philosopher Walter Benjamin wrote about it: this idea that we’re looking forwards, but also always looking back.”

title: The Voters Watching the Debate With a Hand Over Their Eyes
description: Jay Bodenstein, a lifelong Democrat who lives in the Villages retirement community in Florida, plans to sit down this week for a night of television he regards with terror.

title: France’s Far-Right Leader Says the National Rally Is Ready to Govern
description: Jordan Bardella, the president of France’s far-right National Rally, insisted at a news conference on Monday that he would be a prime minister for all French people if his party won the country’s upcoming snap elections, even as he defended his party’s proposal to bar French citizens with dual nationalities from certain “sensitive” jobs.

title: Taylor Swift Notches a Ninth Week at No. 1 With New CD Versions
description: The spring of Taylor Swift has become the summer of Taylor Swift as the singer’s latest album, “The Tortured Poets Department,” holds for a ninth straight week at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart.

title: Film Academy Chief Gets a Sequel: Bill Kramer’s Contract Is Renewed
description: In a time of flux in Hollywood, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the organization that oversees the Oscars, placed a bet on continuity, announcing Monday that it would extend Bill Kramer’s tenure as chief executive through July 2028.

title: The Governor’s Race You Cannot Ignore
description: Partisan hit jobs. Left-wing smears. That’s how Mark Robinson’s aides characterize any attention to his diatribes against Jewish people, gay people, women. They want voters in North Carolina, where he is the Republican nominee for governor, to see him as just another conservative whose straight talk and religiousness come under predictable fire from the ambassadors of wokeness. Nothing to see here, folks, nothing but the usual disdain for MAGA might.

title: ‘Arctic Blast’ of Leaky Water Halts Spacewalk by NASA Astronauts
description: A spacewalk by two NASA astronauts at the International Space Station ended almost as soon as it began on Monday morning when water started squirting from one of the spacesuits into the airlock.

title: Man Pleads Guilty in Home Invasion Using Fake Deadly Virus
description: One of three masked intruders who told a Connecticut multimillionaire and her partner that they had been injected with a lethal virus and would receive the antidote only if they paid $8.5 million has pleaded guilty in the 2007 home invasion, prosecutors said.

title: Tamayo Perry, Professional Surfer, Dies After Shark Attack Off Oahu
description: A lifeguard and professional surfer who grew up on the beaches of Oahu, Hawaii, cementing himself as a local celebrity both in the water and in film and television appearances, died on Sunday after he was attacked by a shark while surfing, the authorities said.

title: What Works for Golf Works for Life
description: Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland, one of the greatest golfers of his generation, suffered a crushing loss at the U.S. Open this month when he missed short putts on two of the last three holes.

title: ‘The Lion King’ at 30: Jason Weaver Sang for Simba but Few Knew It
description: When Jason Weaver arrived at his middle school in Chicago wearing a sweatshirt emblazoned with “The Lion King” logo in 1993, his classmates sneered. The apparel had been a gift from Disney when Weaver recorded the singing voice of young Simba, but the blockbuster animated film had yet to be released.

title: They Came to See Trump. First They Heard a Pitch to Buy Gold and Silver.
description: At a conference this month put on by Turning Point Action, a rising conservative activist group, 8,000 people packed into a Detroit convention hall to hear directly from Republicans’ presumptive nominee for president, Donald J. Trump.

title: Why Do We Love ‘The Bear’ So Much?
description: The first time I heard a stranger say “corner” outside a kitchen, I was taken by surprise, but pretty soon, I lost count. After the FX show “The Bear” began streaming on Hulu in 2022, shouting out phrases that bounce around professional kitchens became something of a national bit.

title: Inside Biden’s Camp David Debate Prep
description: At Camp David, a movie theater and an airplane hangar have been outfitted with lights and production equipment to create a mock debate stage. At least 16 current and former aides, summoned from Washington and Wilmington, whiz back and forth on golf carts to join President Biden in strategy sessions.

title: Washington Post Publisher Says He Aided Hack Inquiry. Scotland Yard Had Doubts.
description: Will Lewis, now the publisher of the Washington Post, was in full crisis mode in 2011. Then an executive at a subsidiary of Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, he was an intermediary to the police detectives investigating a British phone-hacking scandal that had placed the company’s journalists and top leaders in legal peril.

title: Hamas Skimmed $1 Billion in U.N. Aid for Weapons and Tunnels, Suit Says
description: For years, the United Nations Relief and Works Agency sent millions of dollars each month to Gaza to pay employees and support hospitals, schools and other infrastructure, according to a new lawsuit. The money was wired from New York, where the agency has an office, to the West Bank, where financial institutions loaded some of that cash onto trucks to be driven across Israel to Gaza.

title: Frederick Crews, Withering Critic of Freud’s Legacy, Dies at 91
description: Frederick Crews, a literary critic and a leading skeptic in the contentious scholarly debate over the achievements and legacy of Sigmund Freud, died on Friday in Oakland, Calif. He was 91.

title: Former Officer Pleads Guilty to Killing Woman in Ex-Girlfriend’s Home
description: A former New York City police officer pleaded guilty on Thursday to killing a woman she had found in her ex-girlfriend’s apartment and trying to kill the ex-girlfriend as well.

title: More Than 1,300 Die During Extremely Hot Hajj Pilgrimage
description: A Saudi official said most of the deaths involved unregistered pilgrims who lacked access to certain amenities available to those with permits, such as air-conditioned buses and tents.

title: F1 on the Water? Yachts Race at the Statue of Liberty.
description: At 11:30 a.m. Sunday morning, with New York City under a heat advisory, a gaggle of sailing enthusiasts, dressed in polo shirts and summer dresses, boarded a ferry for Governors Island to watch towering F50 catamarans race along the skyline of Lower Manhattan and in front of the Statue of Liberty.

title: Roger Federer’s Graduation Speech Becomes an Online Hit
description: There are thousands of commencement addresses on college campuses each spring. Most are unremarkable and go unremarked upon. But occasionally one gets people talking and gains traction online. That was the case with the speech given by the retired tennis champion Roger Federer at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H., on June 9.

title: Tuesday Briefing: Dagestan Attack Revives Terrorism Fears in Russia
description: At least 20 people were killed on Sunday in a seemingly coordinated assault in the Dagestan region of southern Russia. It was the deadliest attack in the area in 14 years.

title: Louisiana Parents Sue to Block Display of Ten Commandments in Schools
description: A group of parents in Louisiana filed a federal lawsuit on Monday seeking to block a new state law requiring that the Ten Commandments be posted in every public school classroom.

title: Covid Changed Everything, Including How We Cover the Bird Flu
description: Many of the scientists Apoorva Mandavilli spoke to seemed convinced of the same thing: The bird flu virus, called H5N1, could cause the world’s next pandemic.

title: Attacks in Russia’s Dagestan Region: What to Know
description: Two bloody attacks in Dagestan, in southern Russia, on Sunday ignited fears of extremist violence on the home front, as the Kremlin pours resources and bodies into its sprawling war in Ukraine.

title: Biden Is Prepping for the First Debate
description: President Biden has spent the last five days at Camp David, the presidential retreat in the woods of northern Maryland, sparring with a man pretending to be Donald Trump and working with his closest advisers to prepare for this week’s debate.

title: Will the Debate Be ‘Rah-Rah’ or ‘Ruh-Roh?’
description: Good evening. It’s debate week!

title: Israeli Strike Kills Health Official, Gazans Say, as Gallant Visits U.S.
description: An Israeli strike killed a top official in charge of ambulance services in the Gaza Strip, local health officials said on Monday, as the Israeli defense minister met with top American officials in Washington about a possible new phase in the Israeli offensive.

title: Judge Skeptical About Request to Limit Trump Statements on F.B.I.
description: The federal judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s classified documents case posed tough questions on Monday to prosecutors who have asked her to bar him from making inflammatory statements that might endanger any F.B.I. agents involved in the case.

title: Assange Agrees to Plead Guilty in Exchange for Release, Ending Standoff With U.S.
description: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, agreed to plead guilty on Monday to a single felony count of illegally obtaining and disclosing national security material in exchange for his release from a British prison, ending his long and bitter standoff with the United States.

title: County Legislature in N.Y. Suburbs Passes Transgender Athlete Ban
description: A county legislature in New York voted on Monday to bar transgender athletes from playing at county-owned facilities unless they compete on teams matching the gender they were assigned at birth or on coed teams.

title: A Timeline of Julian Assange’s Legal Saga
description: Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder who has long fought extradition from Britain to the United States, agreed on Monday to plead guilty to one count of violating the Espionage Act in exchange for a five-year prison sentence.

title: Election 2024 Polls: Biden vs. Trump
description: Our polling averages track the latest trends in the presidential race, using data from national and battleground state polls.

title: Methodology: How The Times Calculates 2024 Polling Averages
description: The idea behind a poll average is simple: Just average the most recent polls together.

title: Oakland’s Mayor Had Enough Troubles. Then the F.B.I. Came Knocking.
description: The residents of Oakland, Calif., were already frustrated. Violent crime and burglaries had become enough of a problem that getting an In-N-Out burger and fueling up near the airport was considered a risky endeavor.

title: Hoping for a Glimpse of Hailey Bieber, Hundreds Turn Out for Her Makeup
description: The line of Hailey Bieber fans snaked up Greene Street in Manhattan and wrapped around the block, but many were never going to get what they really wanted: a selfie with Mrs. Bieber.

title: Ex-Haitian Gang Leader Is Sentenced to 35 Years in Prison in Gunrunning Scheme
description: The former leader of a Haitian street gang was sentenced on Monday to 35 years in prison for his role in directing a gunrunning scheme that smuggled guns to Haiti using ransom money that had been paid for the release of American hostages, prosecutors said.

title: The Most Important Primary Election of the Year Is Also a Heartbreaker
description: Update: George Latimer defeated Jamaal Bowman in the Democratic congressional primary on Tuesday.

title: Judges Block Parts of Biden’s Student Loan Repayment Plan
description: Two federal judges in Kansas and Missouri temporarily blocked pieces of the Biden administration’s new student loan repayment plan on Monday in rulings that will have implications for millions of federal borrowers.

title: With Virginia Primary Undecided, Rep. Bob Good Seeks Funds for Recount
description: The Republican primary between Representative Bob Good of Virginia, the chairman of the ultraconservative House Freedom Caucus, and his Trump-backed challenger was still undecided on Monday almost a week after the balloting, as the two election deniers settled in for a lengthy and ugly fight over who was the true winner.

title: New Jersey Transit Service Disrupted for Third Time in Less Than a Week
description: New Jersey Transit service was disrupted once again on Monday evening, with travel suspended in and out of Pennsylvania Station for nearly an hour because of a report of a problem with Amtrak overhead wires in one of the Hudson River tunnels.

title: Where Joe Biden and Donald Trump Stand on the Issues
description: Here’s what President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump have done and want to do on abortion, democracy, the economy, immigration, Israel and Gaza, and Social Security and Medicare.

title: Zelensky Removes a Top General Amid Criticism of Excessive Casualties
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine removed one of his top generals from his post on Monday amid public criticism that the commander’s decisions had led to excessive casualties.

title: A User’s Guide to Midlife
description: Experts weigh in on the most vexing issues and changes — and how to deal with them.

title: ‘Is There Any Chance He Can Sit on a Camel?’ A Senator’s Wife Wanted to Know.
description: In March 2019, an aide to Senator Robert Menendez drafted a letter that used strong language to criticize the president of Egypt and the country’s human rights record. Mr. Menendez declined to sign it.

title: ‘Let’s Do This Thing!’
description: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

title: He Stole From His Tech Boss and Killed Him to Conceal the Crime
description: Just days after the body of Fahim Saleh, a successful tech entrepreneur, was found dismembered in his luxury condominium in Manhattan in July 2020, his former personal assistant, Tyrese Haspil, made a series of unsettling web searches.

title: Corrections: June 25, 2024
description: An article on Saturday about The Washington Post’s leadership group misstated Scott Higham’s current status at company. He left The Post in March. He is not currently a reporter there.

title: Quotation of the Day: Realities of Abortion Bans Shift the Terms of the Issue
description: “It’s profoundly personal to a majority of the public.”

title: Where Have All the Chinese I.P.O.s Gone?
description: There was a time when a Chinese internet company’s initial public offering was the hottest thing on Wall Street.

title: How to Watch the Biden-Trump Presidential Debate
description: The moment has been four years in the making: President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump on a debate stage, another flashpoint in their long-running hostilities.

title: 2 Russian Women Put on a Play. Then the State Came for Them.
description: They wrote and staged their play as an indictment of terrorism, examining the deception and depravity of violent extremists and the people whose lives they ruin.

title: China Becomes First Country to Retrieve Rocks From the Moon’s Far Side
description: China brought a capsule full of lunar soil from the far side of the moon down to Earth on Tuesday, achieving the latest success in an ambitious schedule to explore the moon and other parts of the solar system.

title: What to See on London Stages This Summer
description: London’s theaters offer something for everyone. Whether in big West End venues or on stages tucked away above a pub, the city’s shows include the classics, new plays and some productions that defy classification. Open air playhouses attract audiences willing to brave the unpredictable summer weather, and venues spread throughout the city make for an accessible theater landscape that extends far beyond the heavily trafficked tourist hot spots.

title: Tuesday Briefing
description: At least 20 people were killed on Sunday in a seemingly coordinated assault in the Dagestan region of southern Russia, the deadliest attack in the area in 14 years.

title: What Is It About Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Anyway? 12 Voters Explain His Appeal.
description: The participants talk about their frustrations with the two-party system, the appeal of third-party candidates and the issues most important to them in voting for president.

title: Hillary Clinton: I’ve Debated Trump and Biden. Here’s What I’m Watching For.
description: Last week I had the time of my life at the Tony Awards introducing a song from “Suffs,” the Broadway musical I co-produced about the suffragists who won women the right to vote. I was thrilled when the show took home the awards for best original score and best book.

title: An Israeli panel warns Netanyahu over corruption case, and other news.
Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: Is New York Prepared for a Bird Flu Pandemic?
description: Four years after a new coronavirus swept through New York in what was called a once-in-a-century event, public health officials are beginning to prepare for the possibility that a far worse pandemic is on its way.

title: It’s Primary Day in New York. Here’s What to Know.
description: Tuesday is Primary Day in New York.

title: China’s Lunar Craft Returns to Earth
description: Chang’e-6 parachuted down to an area of Inner Mongolia, carrying with it soil samples from the far side of the moon.

title: Gold Medal Looks in Paris
description: The question of inspiration has always been a little cringey when it comes to fashion: Designers offering up “mood board” collages backstage to turn even the genesis of their collections into content and connect them to some deeper meaning that can often seem either ridiculously convoluted or drippingly banal. Hence Miranda Priestley’s famous “Florals? For spring? Groundbreaking” moment in “The Devil Wears Prada.”

title: Israeli Military Must Draft Ultra-Orthodox Jews, Supreme Court Rules
description: Israel’s Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled that the military must begin drafting ultra-Orthodox Jewish men, a decision that threatened to split Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s coalition government amid the war in Gaza.

title: Two Sisters, Joined in Hardship and Separated by a Bear
description: In 2019, a black bear swam out to the San Juan Islands, the lush, lovely archipelago in Washington’s north Puget Sound. The adult male was spotted on six islands before moving on, apparently discouraged by the paucity of mates (or perhaps by the high price of real estate). More than a year later, when I visited the San Juans, the bear was still the talk of the float plane.

title: Year After Failed Mutiny, Russia Tightens Grip on Wagner Units in Africa
description: For years, Russia covertly propped up authoritarian leaders, exploited natural resources and fought extremists in a number of African countries.

title: The Pet ‘Superheroes’ Who Donate Their Blood
description: At first, it was hard to tell whether something was really wrong with Rover. The 10-year-old yellow Lab had always been a bit of a loafer, so when he refused to get up from the rug last February, it was not entirely out of character. But then he declined a treat.

title: An Orcas Island Home Was the Dream. Here’s How They Made It a Reality.
description: A home should be a place where you can welcome your extended family — at least that’s what Leah Martin and Vikram Prakash thought. But while they loved entertaining at the house they shared with their three children, the experience wasn’t quite what they had in mind.

title: Do You Have Food Allergies? Here’s How to Travel Safely.
description: For the 33 million Americans managing any of the most common nine food allergies — including milk, eggs, nuts, wheat, soy, sesame and different types of fish — traveling safely can be challenging, but it’s becoming easier.

title: Kevin Costner Is Pursuing His Western Dream. Will Audiences Follow?
description: Oh, to have the self-confidence of Kevin Costner.

title: The Ballot Measures Aim to Reduce Partisanship. Can They Fix American Politics?
description: Americans of both parties routinely express deep concern about the state of the country’s democracy. This fall, many voters may have a chance to do something about it, by voting on state ballot measures related to the nuts and bolts of elections and governance.

title: What Happened to the Well-Mannered Cat Burglar?
description: As the rich got richer in the boom years of the 1920s, many of them fled New York City noise for the newly fashionable suburbs. But in these tranquil enclaves, they found something else to keep them up at night: a mysterious jewel thief known only as “the phantom.”

title: Léopold Sédar Senghor’s Library Heading to Senegal
description: More than 20 years after the death of Léopold Sédar Senghor — the writer, poet and first president of Senegal after the country’s independence from France — his name is still generating headlines.

title: Is It a Bad Idea to Drink Alcohol on an Airplane?
description: Q: A cocktail or glass of wine helps me fall asleep on long flights. But are there downsides to drinking on a plane?

title: 13 of Our Readers’ Favorite New York City Sandwiches
description: Last week we published a project we’ve been working on for quite a while: a list of 57 sandwiches that define New York City. (Someone named Dave in the comments generously suggested we rename the list, “Making Everyone Who Ever Left NYC Regret Their Choices.”)

title: How America Became the Capital of Great Pizza
description: Marisol Doyle wasn’t bothered by the frozen dough and canned mushrooms common in the pizzas she ate as a kid growing up in Sonora, Mexico. It was comfort food.

title: Mavis Staples Is an American Institution. She’s Not Done Singing Yet.
description: On a rainy April day in Chicago, Mavis Staples sat in the restaurant of the towering downtown Chicago building where she’s lived for the past four years. For two hours, she talked about the civil rights movement and faith. And finally, she mentioned her old flame Bob Dylan.

title: Can a New Leader Make the Boston Symphony Innovative Again?
description: “I’m going to sound like such a dork,” Chad Smith said as he drove a golf cart around the grounds of Tanglewood, the Boston Symphony Orchestra’s pastoral summer home in the Berkshires. “I love Tanglewood so much.”

title: In Defense of Wine
description: Around the globe, much of the wine world is feeling besieged and stigmatized.

title: The Diabolical PBS Show That’ll Restore Your Faith in Reality TV
description: Reality TV has become the victim of its own domination. Today it is all but impossible to find participants unlearned in the folkways of reality television. A “Real Housewives” viewer understands the show as not a documentary about women’s lives but an improvisatory melodrama whose characters strive to be depicted favorably in a documentary about women’s lives. They watch because it is funny, infuriating and at times harrowing to observe people, consumed with awareness of being filmed, trying to give the impression that they are not thinking almost exclusively about being filmed.

title: 22 of the Best Pizza Places in the United States
description: Pizza in America has never been better. The wood-fire Neapolitan pizzerias that took off in the early 2000s, and have been spreading ever since, taught Americans to ask more of a dish they already loved.

title: Scientists Find First Evidence That Butterflies Crossed an Ocean
description: Early one morning in late October 2013, Gerard Talavera, an entomologist, saw something highly unusual — a flock of painted lady butterflies stranded on a beach in French Guiana.

title: Surgeon General Declares Gun Violence a Public Health Crisis
description: The U.S. surgeon general, Dr. Vivek Murthy, on Tuesday declared gun violence in America a public health crisis, recommending an array of preventive measures that he compared to past campaigns against smoking and traffic safety.

title: A Day-Glo New York Where Artists Could Afford the Rent
description: Among the skills that can get a writer out of trouble, a sense of smell should not be underestimated. Stuck for an escape, cornered by the rats of cliché and sentimentality, today’s autofictionists are wont to brandish their anxiety, consort with their inner demons, flash their self-loathing and blame late capitalism — yet a nimbler response might simply be to sniff for fresh air and head for the door.

title: A Brooklyn School District Finds a Path Toward Integration
description: Elected officials who prefer not to discuss the fact that New York City has one of the most segregated school systems in the United States could soon have no choice. A state appellate court has said that an anti-discrimination lawsuit can move forward.

title: The Urgent Need to Blow Off Swing Voters
description: In a presidential election where both leading candidates are unpopular, there’s much talk about what each candidate can say to swing voters in Thursday’s debate. But true swing voters are disengaged from political news; in fact, many avoid it with a determination normally reserved for toxic exes, ticks and food poisoning. To the extent they learn what’s said on Thursday, it’ll be via repackaged clips on social media.

title: Introducing Our 2024 Poll Tracker
description: What do the polls say about the race for the White House?

title: Why Republicans Are Talking About Biden’s ‘Dictatorship’
description: The United States under President Biden is a “dictatorship,” according to Doug Burgum, governor of North Dakota.

title: ‘I Am: Celine Dion’ Review: You Saw the Best in Me
description: Illness shows no regard for even the most revered figures in pop music.

title: Three Ideas to Beat the Heat, and the People Who Made Them Happen
description: An app that helps people find relief from the heat.

title: How Venezuela’s Leader Could Stay in Power, No Matter What Voters Want
description: Venezuela’s authoritarian president, Nicolás Maduro, faces a watershed moment that will determine the fate of his rule and the course of his troubled country.

title: Age and the Image of Capacity
description: “Watch me,” President Biden likes to say when he’s asked — he’s asked a lot, these days — whether he is too old to serve a second term. He is getting his wish.

title: London’s Kew Gardens Has Long Links to Japan. Now the Emperor Is Set to Visit.
description: When Emperor Naruhito of Japan will visit Kew Gardens on Thursday as part of a state visit to Britain, the links between his island nation and the famed London landmark will be on full display.

title: ‘Doctor Who’ Season in Review: The Doctor Might Be on a New Path
description: “Doctor Who” is a show of paradoxes. At its best, it’s a show about a time-traveling, space-venturing alien who ceaselessly untangles the mysteries of the universe, and often invites his own. At its worst, it’s plagued by its contradictions — incoherent or unintelligible narrative logic, inconsistent writing, uneven tone.

title: What Happened to Stanford Spells Trouble for the Election
description: In 2020 the Stanford Internet Observatory, where I was until recently the research director, helped lead a project that studied election rumors and disinformation. As part of that work, we frequently encountered conspiratorial thinking from Americans who had been told the 2020 presidential election was going to be stolen.

title: ‘Babylon Berlin’ Review: Dancing While the World Begins to Burn
description: Far from the eyes of Emmy voters or the digital gremlins compiling streaming Top 10 lists, there is a series — a German period drama, of all things — that a small core of aficionados would argue is the world’s best television show.

title: Today’s Teenagers Have Invented a Language That Captures the World Perfectly
description: My son just completed high school and when he leaves for college in the fall my life will change in ways I’m still struggling to contemplate. Among the things I’ll miss most are his lessons in teenage slang. My son has always been generous with me, and I’ve found the slang of his generation to be so much better and more useful than any that I’ve ever used. His slang has also offered me an accidental and useful portrait of how he and his generation see the world.

title: The Connections Companion No. 381, June 26, 2024
description: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

title: Wordle Review No. 1,103, June 26, 2024
description: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

title: The Plan to Defeat Critics of Israel in Congress
description: A powerful group supporting Israel is trying to defeat sitting members of Congress who have criticized the country’s deadly war against Hamas.

title: Assange Agrees to Plea Deal, and Israel-Lebanon Border Strikes Intensify
description: On Today’s Episode:

title: Deadly Fire Exposes Harsh Conditions Migrant Workers Face in South Korea
description: They were descendants of Koreans who ​moved to Northeast China​, fleeing Japan’s brutal colonial rule ​in the early 20th century. In a twist of history,​ many like them have come to South Korea in recent decades,​ looking for better-paying jobs in their forebears’ homeland, ​now one of the world’s richest countries.

title: Biden’s Polling Progress
description: President Biden has narrowed the gap with Donald Trump in the past few months, but Trump still holds a small lead in the race for the presidency.

title: E.U. Charges Microsoft With Antitrust Violations Over Teams Bundling
description: European Union regulators on Tuesday charged Microsoft with breaking antitrust rules by bundling its Teams video conferencing and collaboration software with a suite of other productivity tools, giving it an unfair advantage over rivals.

title: ‘Babylon Berlin’ Is Back. Here’s What You Need to Know.
description: Over the years, the lavish German noir detective series “Babylon Berlin” has required patience from its American viewers.

title: What Is a Famine and Who Determines That One Exists?
description: A group of global experts said on Tuesday that Gaza is at high risk of famine, but it stopped short of saying that one had begun.

title: I.C.C. Issues Arrest Warrants for 2 Senior Russian Security Officials
description: The International Criminal Court said on Tuesday that it had issued arrest warrants for two top Russian security officials over strikes against civilian targets, delivering a stinging, if largely symbolic, condemnation of the Kremlin’s invasion of neighboring Ukraine.

title: Turning 26 and Struggling to Find Health Insurance? Tell Us About It.
description: A hard-won provision of the Affordable Care Act allows young adults to stay on their family’s insurance until age 26. But after that, those without employer-based insurance face an array of complicated choices, including whether to shop on the insurance plan exchanges, apply for Medicaid or roll the dice and go uninsured.

title: Strike Kills Sister of Hamas’s Political Leader
description: A strike in the northern Gaza Strip killed a sister of Ismail Haniyeh, the political leader of Hamas, and her family on Tuesday, the armed group and a Gazan rescue official said.

title: Inside Nvidia’s $500 Billion Wipeout
description: It looks like another volatile day for Nvidia shareholders. And given the company’s enormous influence on the entire S&P 500, they may not be the only investors facing big swings.

title: Word of the Day: academe
description: The word academe has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 4 in the guest essay “The Problems Only Start With Plagiarism” by Charles Seife:

title: How a Brooklyn District Tackled School Segregation
description: Today we’ll find out what happened when a school district in Brooklyn began an ambitious effort to better integrate its middle schools. We’ll also find out about a decision throwing out an attempt by the city to ban foie gras.

title: Readers Share Their Favorite Parts of 2024 So Far
description: Believe it or not, we’re nearly halfway through 2024. As a midweek pick-me-up, today I’m sharing some of the lovely notes readers have sent me about their favorite parts of this year: new hobbies, graduation ceremonies and more. Send your own tales to CAtoday@nytimes.com.

title: Foreign Police Officers Land on the Ground in Haiti
description: Foreign law enforcement officers began arriving in Haiti on Tuesday, more than a year and a half after the prime minister there issued a plea to other countries for help to stop the rampant gang violence that has upended the Caribbean nation.

title: Russia Committed Human Rights Violations in Crimea, European Court Finds
description: The European Court of Human Rights ruled on Tuesday that Russia and its proxy security forces in Crimea have committed multiple human rights violations during its decade-long occupation of the Ukrainian territory.

title: Leslye Headland’s ‘Cult of Love’ to Open on Broadway in the Fall
description: “Cult of Love,” a play about a fractious holiday gathering of a Christian family, will come to Broadway this fall via Second Stage Theater, one of the four nonprofits with Broadway houses.

title: In States That Won’t Pay for Obesity Drugs, ‘They May as Well Have Never Been Created’
description: Joanna Bailey, a family physician and obesity specialist, doesn’t want to tell her patients that they can’t take Wegovy, but she has gotten used to it.

title: The Four Issues Trump and Biden Will Clash Over at the Debate
description: President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump have sparred for months on the campaign trail, in interviews with reporters and through paid advertisements, creating phantom likenesses of each other to thrash and tear down.

title: When the Runways Are a Personal Playlist
description: If fashion is a storytelling business, it should follow that runway shows are narratives.

title: France’s Far-Right National Rally Rebranded Itself. Here’s How.
description: For decades, the National Rally was the pariah of French politics — deemed so dangerous that politicians from other parties refused to engage with its members.

title: It’s Called the Best Gazpacho Because It Is the Best Gazpacho
description: It’s time for our annual reminder that gazpacho is the queen of summer cooking, a coolly satisfying remedy for intense, sluggish heat. Our recipe is called best gazpacho, and it delivers on that promise. It’s simple, salty, thick and smooth, with no bobbing cubes of cucumber in sight. (I never liked those.)

title: ‘White Chicks’ at 20: Comedy Beyond the Pale
description: When the oversexed basketball player Latrell Spencer (Terry Crews) turns to his date to sing Vanessa Carlton’s “A Thousand Miles,” he does so to prove his total love of all things white. Spencer is the stereotypical embodiment of the lascivious muscular Black man intent on procuring a white woman to prove his own masculinity. “Once you go Black, you’re gonna need a wheelchair,” he says. And yet, despite the broadness of his carnal desires, his performativity is the comedic soul to the director Keenen Ivory Wayans’s astute racial passing satire “White Chicks.”

title: Jonathan Majors Is Cast in First Movie Role Since Assault Conviction
description: Jonathan Majors will lead a feature film for the first time since he was found guilty of assaulting and harassing his girlfriend, a conviction that doomed a lucrative contract with Marvel Studios and imperiled his status as one of the fastest-rising stars in Hollywood.

title: The Pro-Israel Donor With a $100 Million Plan to Elect Trump
description: As the Nevada caucuses drew to a close in February, Donald J. Trump and several top aides gathered for a quick dinner in a suite atop his hotel in Las Vegas before he descended and declared victory.

title: Patients Stunned by Their Medical Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: Jamaal Bowman Deserved to Lose
description: Update: George Latimer defeated Jamaal Bowman in the Democratic congressional primary on Tuesday.

title: How a Cake Became a National Obsession
description: During the Lunar New Year of 1988, Selena Wong wanted to create a special dessert for her family in Kingston, Jamaica. Ms. Wong, whose ancestors came to the island from China in the 19th century, was a self-taught baker who occasionally sold goods from her home.

title: Heat Is Killing Thousands, and Big Events Have Not Adjusted
description: At large events all over the world, the scenes of extreme heat stress are starting to look familiar. Older men, shirts undone, lying down with their eyes closed. Aid tents packed with the unconscious. And lines of the faithful — whether they seek religion, music, ballot boxes or sport — sweating under slivers of shade.

title: Review: In ‘Find Me Here,’ Sisters Grapple With a Father’s Will, and His Legacy
description: Weddings, anniversaries, holidays: The family get-together is a dramatic gift that keeps on giving to both screen and stage. Crystal Finn’s new play, “Find Me Here,” at Wild Project, falls into a subcategory of the funerals subgenre — the opening of a will. In this case, a patriarch’s last wishes are discovered by his three daughters and their families. Truths and conflicts emerge gingerly, almost tentatively, because Finn is less interested in confrontation than in gentle poking and prodding.

title: At Montpellier Danse, Leaning Into New Work as the Void Looms
description: The abyss, the womb, the fathomless depths of sea and space. These are the settings for Wayne McGregor’s new “Deepstaria,” in which nine dancers float and spin, buckle and collapse, regenerate and reform, in a protean display of technical virtuosity and human fragility.

title: Oklahoma Supreme Court Says No to State Funding for a Religious Charter School
description: The Oklahoma Supreme Court blocked on Tuesday what would have been the nation’s first religious charter school, delivering a setback to a conservative movement that has increasingly fought for public dollars to go toward religious education.

title: Seth Binzer, Crazy Town’s Lead Singer, ‘Shifty Shellshock,’ Dies at 49
description: Shifty Shellshock, the lead singer of the late-1990s rap-rock band Crazy Town known for the hit song “Butterfly,” whose legal name was Seth Binzer, died at his home in Los Angeles on Thursday. He was 49.

title: Kraam Dresses in Indigo to Serve Seasonal, Contemporary Thai
description: A sleek white, gold and blue room (kraam means indigo) is the setting for a vibrant, distinctive Thai menu.Instead of the fierce attention to regional cuisines as at beloved Thai spots in Queens, the chef and owner, Pongsathorn Thinnuch, who worked at JoJo and Hutong, and his team of Thai chefs, favor seasonality and contemporary flair. Khao soi curry is made with chicken confit, there are sautéed razor clams with Thai-adjacent chimichurri, and strips of rib-eye heavily strewn with black peppercorns make a stir-fry. The inevitable green papaya salad includes sweet corn and long beans, and you can bet that Giovanni Bellini never tasted his namesake drink with lychee and guava.

title: ‘Costco, Don’t Give Up on America As a Nation of Readers’: The Week 1 Winner of Our Summer Reading Contest
description: For 15 years, our Summer Reading Contest has been inviting teenagers around the world to tell us what New York Times pieces get their attention and why. Up until now, students could only enter by posting short written comments, but this year we’re also allowing 90-second video responses.

title: Deadly Protests Leave Kenya Shocked by Violence
description: A day after demonstrators clashed with the police and stormed the national Parliament building in Kenya to protest passage of a finance bill that would increase taxes, President William Ruto announced on Wednesday that he was changing course and would not sign the legislation.

title: Review: A ‘Ulysses’ That Squeezes Bloomsday Into 2 Hours, 40 Minutes
description: Looking at the stage as you enter the Luma theater, the smaller of the auditoriums at Bard College’s Fisher Center, you might think your ticket had been switched with one for a zoning board meeting. Enjoy the splendor of chairs lined up behind three conjoined conference tables! Admire the care with which pens, stacks of paper and wee bottles of water have been laid like dinner settings! Warily consult the large clock on the upstage wall that offers the real time — at least at first.

title: The Heat Crisis Is a Housing Crisis
description: Air-conditioning was long considered a luxury in much of the world. Not anymore.

title: Boeing Is Said to Offer Stock to Buy Spirit, Preserving Cash Amid Struggles
description: In a bid to acquire a key supplier, Boeing has shifted how it plans to pay for the deal, according to two people familiar with the negotiations, a move that could help the plane maker preserve money as it addresses safety and quality problems.

title: Obama’s Half Sister Is Among Those Tear-Gassed During Protests in Kenya
description: Auma Obama, an older half sister of former President Barack Obama, was tear-gassed on Tuesday while being interviewed live on CNN during protests in Nairobi, the Kenyan capital. The protests were against the passage of a finance bill that raises taxes on many basic goods.

title: Safety Agency Faults Norfolk Southern for ‘Vent and Burn’ After 2023 Derailment
description: The National Transportation Safety Board issued a series of recommendations on Tuesday aimed at preventing the type of freight train derailment that occurred last year in East Palestine, Ohio, when 38 rail cars operated by Norfolk Southern came off the tracks.

title: Why the N.F.L. Put a $7 Billion Antitrust Case in the Hands of an Unpredictable Jury
description: A pillar of the N.F.L.’s meteoric rise over the past six decades has been its strategy of making nearly all games available mostly free to fans on national networks. The league has stuck to this approach even as Major League Baseball, the N.B.A. and other leagues moved more of their games onto cable and satellite broadcasters and subscription streaming services.

title: Assange’s Plea Deal Sets a Chilling Precedent, but It Could Have Been Worse
description: The plea deal Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, has reached with prosecutors is bad for American press freedoms. But the outcome also could have been worse.

title: 7 New Songs You Should Hear Now
description: A few weeks ago, when the British pop musician Charli XCX released her raw, prismatic sixth album, “Brat,” I had some difficulty choosing just one of its tracks for our Friday Playlist. I ultimately went with “Girl, So Confusing,” a dance floor confessional that aired mixed feelings about a certain musical peer. “People say we’re alike, they say we’ve got the same hair,” Charli sang, before admitting that the few times they had hung out felt stilted: “We talk about making music, but I don’t know if it’s honest.”

title: The Southern Border, Terrorism Fears and the Arrests of 8 Tajik Men
description: When eight Tajik men sought asylum at the southwestern U.S. border months ago, federal authorities had no reason to doubt that they were desperate migrants fleeing a poor country in war-torn Central Asia.

title: Trump Can Now Criticize Witnesses Who Testified Against Him, Judge Rules
description: A judge on Tuesday loosened a gag order on Donald J. Trump in his Manhattan criminal case, allowing the former president to criticize witnesses who took the stand against him as well as others involved in the trial that led to his conviction.

description: Faced with demands from two decorated Olympic swimmers, members of Congress expressed an openness on Tuesday to withholding funding from the global regulator assigned to ensure an even Olympic playing field over its refusal to hold accountable Chinese swimmers who tested positive for a banned drug.

title: What to Know About Julian Assange and His Plea Deal
description: Julian Assange spent his youth in Australia during the 1980s in a state of chaotic, perpetual motion. He moved more than two dozen times, bounced from school to school and was thrust, for a time, into what he called a New Age cult, before settling in Melbourne.

title: Kenya Protests Are a Blow to Biden’s Embrace of President Ruto
description: The street turmoil that swept Kenya’s capital on Tuesday represented a blow to the Biden administration’s tight embrace of President William Ruto, a strong U.S. ally on a continent where American influence is rapidly waning.

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘That Was My First Inkling’
description: When I was 7, my grandmother told me she saw Halley’s comet in 1910. As a young woman in rural Tennessee, she was amazed. She explained it would return in 1986, when she’d be in heaven and I’d be a grown man. That was my first inkling, lovingly and mysteriously rendered, that all things change — and people we love pass away, though the stars appear to stay the same. In Seattle, 1986, I watched the comet scar the darkness, my grandmother’s memory burning bright within me. By the time Halley returns in 2061, I will have joined her in infinity. — T.S. Davis

title: He Monitors Solar Flares. Here’s What Keeps Him Up at Night.
description: In May, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration issued a watch for a possible solar storm. A gigantic cluster of spots on the sun was flaring and expelling material headed straight toward Earth.

title: ‘I Might Be Real-Life Good at This’: Shooting for Broadway at the Jimmy Awards
description: Shortly after Damson Chola Jr. sang the powerful “Ragtime” anthem “Make Them Hear You,” in a commanding performance that drove the Minskoff Theater to delirium on Monday night, the young singer accepted the Jimmy Award for best actor. He gave an equally poised acceptance speech, expressing gratitude with a calm cadence and the occasional wry chuckle of someone who’s seen and heard it all.

title: How Much Blush Is Too Much?
description: Jennie Suk, 27, has gotten really into wearing blush in recent months, inspired by videos from TikTok influencers and celebrities, like the singer Sabrina Carpenter, whose dewy, flushed cheeks have become her calling card.

title: Bringing Up Drugs? Undermining the Debate? These Are Old Trump Tactics.
description: To spend time on former President Donald J. Trump’s corner of social media is to witness any number of contradictory, unproven or outright conspiratorial ideas blooming, all at once. The approaching presidential debate has apparently sent him into overdrive.

title: New Jersey Gamer Flew to Florida to Attack Rival With a Hammer, Police Say
description: A New Jersey man who the police said had flown to Florida and attacked a fellow gamer with a hammer over an online dispute was charged with attempted second-degree murder on Sunday.

title: Austin and Russia’s New Defense Minister Speak via Phone for the First Time
description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III spoke by phone on Tuesday with Russia’s new defense minister, Andrei Belousov, the Pentagon said, in a rare conversation between the Biden administration and Moscow.

title: Another Real Estate Broker Steps Down in the Face of Sex Assault Suits
description: Tal Alexander, whose portfolio of luxury real estate transactions includes some of New York and Miami’s most eye-popping sales, is stepping down from the high-end brokerage he co-founded in the wake of mounting allegations of sexual assault.
